576fe93215d6.name: Welcom' to Paris

2a4d8adfaaaa.bio: Computer Engineering Student, Formula 1 Lover, Windows Phone/ Windows 8 developer, tech-journalist-to-be
2a4d8adfaaaa.name: Kaizhi Meng

9d27e24087b1.bio: Professional chef, father, and husband. I have always had a love of cooking. Families sitting down for a family meal is the most important part of life.
9d27e24087b1.name: Brian Bujeau

ae72b162da0c.bio: Researcher at heart, loves to understand human behaviour, author of upcoming book: China Unseen — https://www.facebook.com/ChinaUnseen/
ae72b162da0c.name: Utsav Mamoria

paragraphs.text: Parisians, Vancouverites, and San Franciscans may feel similarly. But Louis Vitton, Gucci and Apple (AAPL: 143.34) don’t seem to care. I’ve talked to many local businesses all over the world who complain about the Chinese, but who readily accept their cash.
Anyway, thanks for writing and sharing this amazing story, it changed our view on Chinese tourists :)
This article changed my perspective. Thank you for reminding us to be empathetic and understanding of other peoples’ experiences.

paragraphs.text: I really enjoyed this article and it has made me think much deeper about the fact that we all have stories of our own that influence our behaviour, sometimes these may be unconscious influences. Never judge is sound advice ❤️

content.subtitle: But that’s OK — we just wait for the next one. And here’s something really cool — the bus company has installed a system on (some of) these…

paragraphs.text: There’s a bus service that runs from Sheffield railway station, almost past my house, and on out into the Derbyshire Peak District to the small town of Bakewell. Going one way or the other the bus diverts to call at Chatsworth House, a stately home (actually, a palace….). Somehow that trip to Chatsworth has got onto young Chinese students’ tourist…

paragraphs.text: Beautiful. I love how you put everything in to perspective. I also think traveling with a large tour group is much safer than wandering by yourself. It’s wonderful that you took the time to share your experiences with us. Thank you.

54a0b5352161.title: We can confess that in Paris, we don’t like tourists.

content.subtitle: But we like to meet travellers : people curious about local life, that we are always ready to help.

paragraphs.name: da3c
paragraphs.text: We can confess that in Paris, we don’t like tourists. Tourists in large groups, to be precise. But the fact is, we appreciate that they want to see our city, but they are a major problem : too many coaches inside our streets, we can’t access our museums and Grands Magasins anymore, and the worst is : they are only here to take pictures of all the…

paragraphs.text: L: Thank you for sharing your experience, mindset, and empathy.

6670e55bc856.title: I also wonder the same things.

paragraphs.text: I also wonder the same things. My intention is not to excuse poor behavior. My intention is to help increase understanding and perspective. Frankly, being someone who is often embarrassed by the poor behavior of some/many Chinese tour groups, this essay as more catharsis for myself in being less judgmental to my own people. Thanks for sharing your perspective, Michael.

paragraphs.name: d210
paragraphs.text: Thank you for writing this. As someone who lived in China and has seen these groups in China as well, I completely agree with you that we need to see the Chinese in context of their recent history and the times they grew up in. Living through the Great Depression and Cultural Revolution would irrevocably change anyone. We are all people shaped by our…

5d173da3b444.title: I’ve been really touched by people like you who have responded here and privately for your ability…

paragraphs.name: 5d13
paragraphs.text: I’ve been really touched by people like you who have responded here and privately for your ability to change perspectives, Denise. Thank you.

No, it isn’t. Definitely goes both ways. Which is why I think it’s so important for an insular, 92% ethnically homogenous nation like China to have it’s people travel outside its own borders, even if in large packs.

c27910d233b7.title: Robert: I’m moved by your story, your self-reflection, and your openheartedness.

paragraphs.name: b1f7
paragraphs.text: Robert: I’m moved by your story, your self-reflection, and your openheartedness. I’m a cyclist and runner as well, and whenever I’m in China I think about how out of the ordinary it would be to see a cyclist riding for anything other than utility/locomotion. That jogger’s nod and wave here in the US? You can bet that happens in China, because if you…

content.subtitle: I’ve met a (very) few nice mainland Chinese when travelling, I’ve also experienced the extremely loud, extremely rude, line cutting…

paragraphs.name: e828
paragraphs.text: I do wonder what the reaction would be if this was written from the perspective of a white person. “Oh you should excuse them when they break local customs, offend people, are rude and entitled; it is just what they are used to at home.” Would that fly?

paragraphs.name: c020
paragraphs.text: Thank your reading.

Great article, Panpan Wang. Brought lots of chuckles. Btw, mainland Chinese tourists aren’t the only groups who are looked down upon by others. Heck, having your whole people labeled by derogatory terms like gweilo or guizi or ang mo is not exactly respectful now, is it?
